questions.question_text_1: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A company plans to do a house-to-house field survey to find the penetration of broadband connections. The required sample size is 300, spread across middle and upper income households
question_texts: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A company plans to do a house-to-house field survey to find the penetration of broadband connections. The required sample size is 300, spread across middle and upper income households

questions.question_text_1: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A bank wants to do a customer satisfaction study over phone, with a sample size of 2000 customers.
question_texts: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A bank wants to do a customer satisfaction study over phone, with a sample size of 2000 customers.

questions.question_text_1: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  An FMCG firm wants to interview a sample of retailers to find out why its brand of soap is not doing well. The required sample size is 25, and the nature of probing will be in-depth.
question_texts: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  An FMCG firm wants to interview a sample of retailers to find out why its brand of soap is not doing well. The required sample size is 25, and the nature of probing will be in-depth.

questions.question_text_1: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A baby products company plans to test out a new concept among mothers of one year old children. The targeted sample size is 30 and the probing will be qualitative in nature
question_texts: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A baby products company plans to test out a new concept among mothers of one year old children. The targeted sample size is 30 and the probing will be qualitative in nature

questions.question_text_1: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A company that makes printers plans to do a customer satisfaction survey amongst its customers, and wants a Pro Rata representation of the various segments. The targeted sample size is 200
question_texts: For the following situation, what sampling method is optimal?  A company that makes printers plans to do a customer satisfaction survey amongst its customers, and wants a Pro Rata representation of the various segments. The targeted sample size is 200

questions.question_text_1: Answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: A manufacturer of readymade garments for men wants to do a sample survey about the brand standing of its brand. It plans to do a house-to-house multistage cluster sampling survey. The company classifies its customers based on collar size (L / M / S) and age (Young / Middle-aged / Elder) and customizes its designs accordingly. The company wants to do the study in only one city. The company wants have a robust sample size with no compromises. What should be the sample size?
question_texts: A manufacturer of readymade garments for men wants to do a sample survey about the brand standing of its brand. It plans to do a house-to-house multistage cluster sampling survey. The company classifies its customers based on collar size (L / M / S) and age (Young / Middle-aged / Elder) and customizes its designs accordingly. The company wants to do the study in only one city. The company wants have a robust sample size with no compromises. What should be the sample size?
Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: The same company now decides to do a satisfaction study among its own customers and decides that the key metric will be the mean satisfaction score (measured on a 5 point scale). The company wants to be 95% confident that the findings on the mean satisfaction score is plus or minus 10% accurate. What should be the sample size?
question_texts: The same company now decides to do a satisfaction study among its own customers and decides that the key metric will be the mean satisfaction score (measured on a 5 point scale). The company wants to be 95% confident that the findings on the mean satisfaction score is plus or minus 10% accurate. What should be the sample size?
Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: If the company instead decides that the key metric is the percentage of satisfied customers, and wants the same level of accuracy (plus or minus 10% accurate) and confidence (95%), then what should be the sample size?
question_texts: If the company instead decides that the key metric is the percentage of satisfied customers, and wants the same level of accuracy (plus or minus 10% accurate) and confidence (95%), then what should be the sample size?
Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: The family consists of Mr. R who is 73, his wife Mrs. A who is 69, his son MK who is 36 (all of whom live in the same house in Bangalore), his daughter P who lives in Aberdeen in Scotland, and his elder son RK who lives in Delhi.  Mr. R is a retired govt servant and runs the family on his pension, with some monetary support from his elder son. Mrs. A has always been a homemaker and continues to cook and keep house for the family. MK is setting up a business and has no settled earnings yet. RK works for a software firm and earns Rs. 3L per month, while P works in an university in Scotland and earns 40,000 UK pounds per year.  From the above example, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: The family consists of Mr. R who is 73, his wife Mrs. A who is 69, his son MK who is 36 (all of whom live in the same house in Bangalore), his daughter P who lives in Aberdeen in Scotland, and his elder son RK who lives in Delhi.  Mr. R is a retired govt servant and runs the family on his pension, with some monetary support from his elder son. Mrs. A has always been a homemaker and continues to cook and keep house for the family. MK is setting up a business and has no settled earnings yet. RK works for a software firm and earns Rs. 3L per month, while P works in an university in Scotland and earns 40,000 UK pounds per year.  From the above example, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Close ended questions give better results than open-ended questions only when the options provided are well thought through and comprehensive.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Close ended questions give better results than open-ended questions only when the options provided are well thought through and comprehensive.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Open-ended questions rarely provide the required depth because the interviewer doesn’t probe well enough.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Open-ended questions rarely provide the required depth because the interviewer doesn’t probe well enough.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Prior experience in reading the results is one of the key criteria in choice of scale.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Prior experience in reading the results is one of the key criteria in choice of scale.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  In the absence of other information, it is always safer to use a balanced scale than an unbalanced scale.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  In the absence of other information, it is always safer to use a balanced scale than an unbalanced scale.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  When we provide a mid-point in a scale, we are encouraging the respondent to choose it without due thought.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  When we provide a mid-point in a scale, we are encouraging the respondent to choose it without due thought.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Scales should be designed in such a way that the distribution of responses over the scale follow a normal curve.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Scales should be designed in such a way that the distribution of responses over the scale follow a normal curve.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  One way to ensure a good translation of a questionnaire is to write the questionnaire in the vernacular.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  One way to ensure a good translation of a questionnaire is to write the questionnaire in the vernacular.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Awareness and behaviour questions are easier to design and answer than opinion questions.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  Awareness and behaviour questions are easier to design and answer than opinion questions.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  The scale shown here is an unbalanced scale since it doesn’t have a mid-point – very dissatisfied, somewhat dissatisfied, somewhat satisfied, very satisfied.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  The scale shown here is an unbalanced scale since it doesn’t have a mid-point – very dissatisfied, somewhat dissatisfied, somewhat satisfied, very satisfied.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  It is better to ask a respondent “which brands have you heard of?” than to ask “which brands are salient in your mind”.
question_texts: Statement with respect to questionnaire design and scales.  It is better to ask a respondent “which brands have you heard of?” than to ask “which brands are salient in your mind”.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Group discussions are the preferred technique for laddering technique.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Group discussions are the preferred technique for laddering technique.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Depth interviews are the preferred technique for laddering technique because the individual nodal points can be identified.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Depth interviews are the preferred technique for laddering technique because the individual nodal points can be identified.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  A moderator is someone who speaks multiple languages.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  A moderator is someone who speaks multiple languages.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Group discussions should be conducted in a room where there no audio recording or video recording.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Group discussions should be conducted in a room where there no audio recording or video recording.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Grouping of brands is a good way to identify the underlying dimensions which consumers use to choose brands in a category.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Grouping of brands is a good way to identify the underlying dimensions which consumers use to choose brands in a category.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Projective techniques are very powerful but only when handled by a good moderator.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Projective techniques are very powerful but only when handled by a good moderator.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  High involvement categories probably lend themselves better to qualitative research than low involvement categories.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  High involvement categories probably lend themselves better to qualitative research than low involvement categories.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  The best way to moderate a group discussion is to choose one of the respondents as the moderator.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  The best way to moderate a group discussion is to choose one of the respondents as the moderator.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  It is better to have articulate respondents who speak well rather than shy respondents who don’t speak much, for a qualitative study.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  It is better to have articulate respondents who speak well rather than shy respondents who don’t speak much, for a qualitative study.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Qualitative research generally uses convenience sampling.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Qualitative research generally uses convenience sampling.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Estimating demand for a new product requires quantitative research.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Estimating demand for a new product requires quantitative research.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Qualitative research does a better job of understand the image of a brand in consumers’ minds.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Qualitative research does a better job of understand the image of a brand in consumers’ minds.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Packaging cues are better handled in quantitative research.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Packaging cues are better handled in quantitative research.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  The best application of qualitative research is to understand the underlying thought process of consumers.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  The best application of qualitative research is to understand the underlying thought process of consumers.

questions.question_text_1: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Depth interviews are the best technique for exploratory research.
question_texts: Statement with respect to qualitative research.  Depth interviews are the best technique for exploratory research.

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### Core Topics and Concepts

1. **Sampling Methods**
   - **Multistage Cluster Sampling**: Used for large geographical areas, involves multiple stages of sampling.
   - **Stratified Sampling**: Divides the population into subgroups (strata) and samples from each stratum.
   - **Quota Sampling**: Non-probability sampling where the sample is selected based on predefined quotas.
   - **Systematic Sampling**: Selects elements from an ordered sampling frame, typically at a fixed periodic interval.
   - **Convenience Sampling**: Uses subjects who are convenient and readily available.

2. **Sample Size Determination**
   - **Confidence Level and Margin of Error**: Key factors in determining sample size.
   - **Formulas for Sample Size**:
     - For estimating means:
       \[
       n = \left( \frac{Z \times \sigma}{E} \right)^2
       \]
       where \( Z \) is the Z-score, \( \sigma \) is the standard deviation, and \( E \) is the margin of error.
     - For estimating proportions:
       \[
       n = \frac{Z^2 \times p \times (1-p)}{E^2}
       \]
       where \( p \) is the estimated proportion.

3. **Socio-Economic Classification (SEC)**
   - **Grid for Urban SEC**: Classification based on occupation and education levels.
   - **Chief Wage Earner and Housewife/Householder**: Identification based on income and household management.

4. **Questionnaire Design and Scales**
   - **Close-ended vs. Open-ended Questions**: Close-ended questions provide specific options, while open-ended questions allow for free responses.
   - **Balanced vs. Unbalanced Scales**: Balanced scales have an equal number of positive and negative options, while unbalanced scales do not.
   - **Mid-point in Scales**: Encourages respondents to choose a neutral option.
   - **Translation of Questionnaires**: Ensuring accurate translation for vernacular languages.

5. **Qualitative Research**
   - **Group Discussions and Depth Interviews**: Techniques for qualitative data collection.
   - **Laddering Technique**: Used to understand the underlying thought processes of consumers.
   - **Moderator Role**: Facilitates group discussions and depth interviews.
   - **Projective Techniques**: Powerful tools when handled by a skilled moderator.
   - **High vs. Low Involvement Categories**: High involvement categories are better suited for qualitative research.

#### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Market Research] --> B[Sampling Methods]
    A --> C[Sample Size Determination]
    A --> D[Socio-Economic Classification]
    A --> E[Questionnaire Design]
    A --> F[Qualitative Research]

    B --> B1[Multistage Cluster Sampling]
    B --> B2[Stratified Sampling]
    B --> B3[Quota Sampling]
    B --> B4[Systematic Sampling]
    B --> B5[Convenience Sampling]

    C --> C1[Confidence Level]
    C --> C2[Margin of Error]
    C --> C3[Formulas for Sample Size]

    D --> D1[Chief Wage Earner]
    D --> D2[Housewife/Householder]
    D --> D3[SEC Grid]

    E --> E1[Close-ended Questions]
    E --> E2[Open-ended Questions]
    E --> E3[Balanced Scales]
    E --> E4[Unbalanced Scales]
    E --> E5[Mid-point in Scales]
    E --> E6[Translation of Questionnaires]

    F --> F1[Group Discussions]
    F --> F2[Depth Interviews]
    F --> F3[Laddering Technique]
    F --> F4[Moderator Role]
    F --> F5[Projective Techniques]
    F --> F6[High vs. Low Involvement Categories]
```

This summary and knowledge graph should help you understand the core topics and their relationships for the exam on "Degree Level: Market Research."
